newsitem.title: USA: Informix unveils huge loss, says CFO quits.
newsitem.headline: Informix unveils huge loss, says CFO quits.

text.p: Informix Corp. on Thursday reported a huge first-quarter loss, as expected, and unveiled a restructuring plan that will include job cuts and an unspecified charge in the second quarter.
Informix, the second-biggest publisher of database software, also said Chief Financial Officer Alan Henricks, who had been on the job only since January, resigned.
The company, based in Menlo Park, Calif., said it will not report a profit for at least another two quarters.
Informix is reeling from product miscues. In December, the compay introduced Universal Server, an advanced database product.
Although Informix's new products have been praised by technology analysts, customers so far have not been willing to base critical record-keeping systems on them.

Informix reported a first-quarter loss of $140.1 million, or 93 cents a share, compared with net income of $15.9 million, or 10 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. The company had warned a month ago that it would report a significant loss.
First-quarter revenue plunged 34 percent to $133.7 million from $204 million.
Informix said it will shut some operations and lay off an unspecified number of workers. To cover the cost, the company will take a charge in the second quarter, which ends in June.
The company also consolidated various product sales teams into one group.

"It will take the second quarter to get in shape. It will take the third-quarter to get business to ramp up, and hopefully by the end of the year we'll break even," said Phil White, Informix chief executive.
The company also said CFO Henricks resigned. White said he understood Henrick's decision to leave. Henricks was caught by surprise by the size of Informix's shortfall.
"Alan came here to be part of a billion-dollar software company," White said. "He doesn't feel this is the place he wants to be going forward."
In a statement, Henricks said the decision was difficult "coming as it does at an awkward time for Informix. This is a company with excellent products."
In early trading on Nasdaq, Informix shares were down 50 cents at $6.813.
